template.name: Windows by Zabbix agent
template.description:
Official Windows template. Requires agent of Zabbix 7.0 and newer.
You can discuss this template or leave feedback on our forum https://www.zabbix.com/forum/zabbix-suggestions-and-feedback/387224-discussion-thread-for-official-zabbix-template-for-windows
Generated by official Zabbix template tool "Templator" 2.0.0

item.name: Windows: Host name of Zabbix agent running
Windows: Zabbix agent ping
item.description: The agent always returns 1 for this item. It could be used in combination with nodata() for availability check.

item.name: Windows: Version of Zabbix agent running
Windows: Cache bytes
item.description: Cache Bytes is the sum of the Memory\\System Cache Resident Bytes, Memory\\System Driver Resident Bytes, Memory\\System Code Resident Bytes, and Memory\\Pool Paged Resident Bytes counters. This counter displays the last observed value only; it is not an average.

item.name: Windows: Free system page table entries
item.description: This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak or you running out of memory.

trigger.expression: max(/Windows by Zabbix agent/perf_counter_en["\Memory\Free System Page Table Entries"],5m)<{$MEM.PAGE_TABLE_CRIT.MIN}
trigger.name: Windows: Number of free system page table entries is too low
trigger.event_name: Windows: Number of free system page table entries is too low (less {$MEM.PAGE_TABLE_CRIT.MIN} for 5m)
trigger.description: The Memory Free System Page Table Entries is less than {$MEM.PAGE_TABLE_CRIT.MIN} for 5 minutes. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

item.name: Windows: Memory page faults per second
item.description: Page Faults/sec is the average number of pages faulted per second. It is measured in number of pages faulted per second because only one page is faulted in each fault operation, hence this is also equal to the number of page fault operations. This counter includes both hard faults (those that require disk access) and soft faults (where the faulted page is found elsewhere in physical memory.) Most processors can handle large numbers of soft faults without significant consequence. However, hard faults, which require disk access, can cause significant delays.

item.name: Windows: Memory pages per second
item.description: This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

trigger.name: Windows: The Memory Pages/sec is too high
trigger.event_name: Windows: The Memory Pages/sec is too high (over {$MEM.PAGE_SEC.CRIT.MAX} for 5m)
trigger.description: The Memory Pages/sec in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$MEM.PAGE_SEC.CRIT.MAX}. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

item.name: Windows: Memory pool non-paged
item.description: This measures the size, in bytes, of the non-paged pool. This is an area of system memory for objects that cannot be written to disk but instead must remain in physical memory as long as they are allocated. There is a possible memory leak if the value is greater than 175MB (or 100MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2019 is recorded in the system event log.

item.name: Windows: Used swap space in %
item.description: The used space of swap volume/file in percent.

item.name: Windows: CPU DPC time
item.description: Processor DPC time is the time that a single processor spent receiving and servicing deferred procedure calls (DPCs). DPCs are interrupts that run at a lower priority than standard interrupts. % DPC Time is a component of % Privileged Time because DPCs are executed in privileged mode. If a high % DPC Time is sustained, there may be a processor bottleneck or an application or hardware related issue that can significantly diminish overall system performance.

item.name: Windows: CPU interrupt time
item.description: The Processor Information\% Interrupt Time is the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. This is an easy way to identify a potential hardware failure. This should never be higher than 20%.

trigger.expression: min(/Windows by Zabbix agent/perf_counter_en["\Processor Information(_total)\% Interrupt Time"],5m)>{$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}
trigger.name: Windows: CPU interrupt time is too high
trigger.event_name: Windows: CPU interrupt time is too high (over {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: "The CPU Interrupt Time in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}%." The Processor Information\% Interrupt Time is the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. This is an easy way to identify a potential hardware failure. This should never be higher than 20%.

item.name: Windows: CPU privileged time
item.description: The Processor Information\% Privileged Time counter shows the percent of time that the processor is spent executing in Kernel (or Privileged) mode. Privileged mode includes services interrupts inside Interrupt Service Routines (ISRs), executing Deferred Procedure Calls (DPCs), Device Driver calls and other kernel-mode functions of the WindowsÂ® Operating System.

trigger.expression: min(/Windows by Zabbix agent/perf_counter_en["\Processor Information(_total)\% Privileged Time"],5m)>{$CPU.PRIV.CRIT.MAX}
trigger.name: Windows: CPU privileged time is too high
trigger.event_name: Windows: CPU privileged time is too high (over {$CPU.PRIV.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: The CPU privileged time in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.PRIV.CRIT.MAX}%.

dependency.name: Windows: CPU interrupt time is too high
dependency.expression: min(/Windows by Zabbix agent/perf_counter_en["\Processor Information(_total)\% Interrupt Time"],5m)>{$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}

item.name: Windows: CPU user time
item.description: The Processor Information\% User Time counter shows the percent of time that the processor(s) is spent executing in User mode.

item.name: Windows: Context switches per second
item.description: Context Switches/sec is the combined rate at which all processors on the computer are switched from one thread to another. Context switches occur when a running thread voluntarily relinquishes the processor, is preempted by a higher priority ready thread, or switches between user-mode and privileged (kernel) mode to use an Executive or subsystem service. It is the sum of Thread\\Context Switches/sec for all threads running on all processors in the computer and is measured in numbers of switches. There are context switch counters on the System and Thread objects. This counter displays the difference between the values observed in the last two samples, divided by the duration of the sample interval.

item.name: Windows: CPU queue length
item.description: The Processor Queue Length shows the number of threads that are observed as delayed in the processor Ready Queue and are waiting to be executed.

item.name: Windows: Number of threads
item.description: The number of threads used by all running processes.

item.name: Windows: Number of processes
item.description: The number of processes.

item.name: Windows: CPU utilization
item.description: The CPU utilization expressed in %.

trigger.name: Windows: High CPU utilization
trigger.description: The CPU utilization is too high. The system might be slow to respond.

item.name: Windows: System name
item.description: The host name of the system.

trigger.expression: change(/Windows by Zabbix agent/system.hostname) and length(last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/system.hostname))>0
trigger.name: Windows: System name has changed
trigger.event_name: Windows: System name has changed (new name: {ITEM.VALUE})
trigger.description: The name of the system has changed. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

item.name: Windows: System local time
item.description: The local system time of the host.

trigger.name: Windows: System time is out of sync
trigger.event_name: Windows: System time is out of sync (diff with Zabbix server > {$SYSTEM.FUZZYTIME.MAX}s)
trigger.description: The host's system time is different from Zabbix server time.

item.name: Windows: Operating system architecture
item.description: The architecture of the operating system.

trigger.expression: change(/Windows by Zabbix agent/system.sw.os) and length(last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/system.sw.os))>0
trigger.name: Windows: Operating system description has changed
trigger.description: The description of the operating system has changed. Possible reasons are that the system has been updated or replaced. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

dependency.name: Windows: System name has changed
dependency.expression: change(/Windows by Zabbix agent/system.hostname) and length(last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/system.hostname))>0

item.name: Windows: Free swap space
item.description: The free space of the swap volume/file expressed in bytes.

item.name: Windows: Free swap space in %
item.description: The free space of the swap volume/file expressed in %.

item.name: Windows: Total swap space
item.description: The total space of the swap volume/file expressed in bytes.

item.name: Windows: System description
item.description: System description of the host.

item.name: Windows: Uptime
item.description: The system uptime expressed in the following format: "N days, hh:mm:ss".

trigger.name: Windows: Host has been restarted
trigger.description: The device uptime is less than 10 minutes.

item.name: Windows: Get filesystems
item.description: The `vfs.fs.get` key acquires raw information set about the file systems. Later to be extracted by preprocessing in dependent items.

item.name: Windows: Total memory
item.description: The total memory expressed in bytes.

item.name: Windows: Used memory
item.description: Used memory in bytes.

item.name: Windows: Memory utilization
item.description: Memory utilization in %.

trigger.name: Windows: High memory utilization
trigger.description: The system is running out of free memory.

item.name: Windows: Network interfaces WMI get
item.key: wmi.getall[root\cimv2,"select Name,Description,NetConnectionID,Speed,AdapterTypeId,NetConnectionStatus,GUID from win32_networkadapter where PhysicalAdapter=True and NetConnectionStatus>0"]
item.description: Raw data of win32_networkadapter.

item.name: Windows: Number of cores
item.description: The number of logical processors available on the computer.

item.name: Windows: Zabbix agent availability
item.description: Monitoring the availability status of the agent.

trigger.name: Windows: Zabbix agent is not available
trigger.event_name: Windows: Zabbix agent is not available (for {$AGENT.TIMEOUT})
trigger.description: For passive only agents, host availability is used with {$AGENT.TIMEOUT} as time threshold.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: The number of incoming packets dropped on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: The number of incoming packets with errors on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits received
item_prototype.description: Incoming traffic on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: The number of outgoing packets dropped on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: The number of outgoing packets with errors on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits sent
item_prototype.description: Outgoing traffic on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Speed
item_prototype.description: Estimated bandwidth of the network interface if any.

master_item.key: wmi.getall[root\cimv2,"select Name,Description,NetConnectionID,Speed,AdapterTypeId,NetConnectionStatus,GUID from win32_networkadapter where PhysicalAdapter=True and NetConnectionStatus>0"]

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Operational status
item_prototype.description: The operational status of the network interface.

master_item.key: wmi.getall[root\cimv2,"select Name,Description,NetConnectionID,Speed,AdapterTypeId,NetConnectionStatus,GUID from win32_networkadapter where PhysicalAdapter=True and NetConnectionStatus>0"]

trigger_prototype.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"])<>2 and (last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"],#1)<>last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"],#2))
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
trigger_prototype.description:
This trigger expression works as follows: 1. It can be triggered if the operations status is down. 2. `{$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1` - a user can redefine context macro to value - 0. That marks this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down. 3. `{TEMPLATE_NAME:METRIC.diff()}=1` - the trigger fires only if the operational status was up to (1) sometime before (so, do not fire for the 'eternal off' interfaces.)
WARNING: if closed manually - it will not fire again on the next poll, because of .diff.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Interface type
item_prototype.description: The type of the network interface.

master_item.key: wmi.getall[root\cimv2,"select Name,Description,NetConnectionID,Speed,AdapterTypeId,NetConnectionStatus,GUID from win32_networkadapter where PhysicalAdapter=True and NetConnectionStatus>0"]

trigger_prototype.expression: change(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.speed["{#IFGUID}"])<0 and last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.speed["{#IFGUID}"])>0 and last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"])=2
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototype.description: This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"])<>2 and (last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"],#1)<>last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"],#2))

trigger_prototype.expression: (avg(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.in["{#IFGUID}"],15m)>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.speed["{#IFGUID}"]) or avg(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.out["{#IFGUID}"],15m)>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.speed["{#IFGUID}"])) and last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.speed["{#IFGUID}"])>0
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: avg(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.in["{#IFGUID}"],15m)<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.speed["{#IFGUID}"]) and avg(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.out["{#IFGUID}"],15m)<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.speed["{#IFGUID}"])
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High bandwidth usage
trigger_prototype.description: The utilization of the network interface is close to its estimated maximum bandwidth.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"])<>2 and (last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"],#1)<>last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"],#2))

trigger_prototype.expression: min(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.in["{#IFGUID}",errors],5m)>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} or min(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.out["{#IFGUID}",errors],5m)>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: max(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.in["{#IFGUID}",errors],5m)<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8 and max(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.out["{#IFGUID}",errors],5m)<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High error rate
trigger_prototype.description: It recovers when it is below 80% of the `{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}` threshold.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"])<>2 and (last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"],#1)<>last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/net.if.status["{#IFGUID}"],#2))

master_item.key: wmi.getall[root\cimv2,"select Name,Description,NetConnectionID,Speed,AdapterTypeId,NetConnectionStatus,GUID from win32_networkadapter where PhysicalAdapter=True and NetConnectionStatus>0"]

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk utilization by idle time
item_prototype.description: This item is the percentage of elapsed time that the selected disk drive was busy servicing read or writes requests based on idle time.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk is overloaded
trigger_prototype.description: The disk appears to be under heavy load.

dependency.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read request responses are too high
{#DEVNAME}: Disk write request responses are too high

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Average disk read queue length
item_prototype.description: Average disk read queue, the number of requests outstanding on the disk at the time the performance data is collected.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read request avg waiting time
item_prototype.description: The average time for read requests issued to the device to be served. This includes the time spent by the requests in queue and the time spent servicing them.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read request responses are too high
trigger_prototype.event_name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read request responses are too high (read > {$VFS.DEV.READ.AWAIT.WARN:"{#DEVNAME}"}s for 15m)
trigger_prototype.description: This trigger might indicate the disk {#DEVNAME} saturation.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write request avg waiting time
item_prototype.description: The average time for write requests issued to the device to be served. This includes the time spent by the requests in queue and the time spent servicing them.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write request responses are too high
trigger_prototype.event_name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write request responses are too high (write > {$VFS.DEV.WRITE.AWAIT.WARN:"{#DEVNAME}"}s for 15m)
trigger_prototype.description: This trigger might indicate the disk {#DEVNAME} saturation.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Average disk write queue length
item_prototype.description: Average disk write queue, the number of requests outstanding on the disk at the time the performance data is collected.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk average queue size (avgqu-sz)
item_prototype.description: The current average disk queue; the number of requests outstanding on the disk while the performance data is being collected.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read rate
item_prototype.description: Rate of read operations on the disk.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write rate
item_prototype.description: Rate of write operations on the disk.

discovery_rule.name: Windows services discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of Windows services of different types as defined in template's macros.

trigger_prototype.name: "{#SERVICE.NAME}" ({#SERVICE.DISPLAYNAME}) is not running
trigger_prototype.description: The service has a state other than "Running" for the last three times.

discovery_rule.name: Mounted filesystem discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of file systems of different types.

item_prototype.name: {#FSLABEL}({#FSNAME}): Space utilization
item_prototype.description: Space utilization expressed in % for `{#FSNAME}`.

item_prototype.name: {#FSLABEL}({#FSNAME}): Total space
item_prototype.description: The total space expressed in bytes.

item_prototype.name: {#FSLABEL}({#FSNAME}): Used space
item_prototype.description: Used storage expressed in bytes.

trigger_prototype.expression: last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},pused])>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and ((last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},total])-last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},used]))<{$VFS.FS.FREE.MIN.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} or timeleft(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},pused],1h,100)<1d)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSLABEL}({#FSNAME}): Disk space is critically low
trigger_prototype.description: Two conditions should match: 1. The first condition - utilization of the space should be above `{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}`. 2. The second condition should be one of the following: - the disk free space is less than `{$VFS.FS.FREE.MIN.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}`; - the disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

trigger_prototype.expression: last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},pused])>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"} and ((last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},total])-last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},used]))<{$VFS.FS.FREE.MIN.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"} or timeleft(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},pused],1h,100)<1d)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSLABEL}({#FSNAME}): Disk space is low
trigger_prototype.description: Two conditions should match: 1. The first condition - utilization of the space should be above `{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}`. 2. The second condition should be one of the following: - the disk free space is less than `{$VFS.FS.FREE.MIN.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}`; - the disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

dependency.name: {#FSLABEL}({#FSNAME}): Disk space is critically low
dependency.expression: last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},pused])>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and ((last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},total])-last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},used]))<{$VFS.FS.FREE.MIN.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} or timeleft(/Windows by Zabbix agent/vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},pused],1h,100)<1d)

macro.description: Timeout after which agent is considered unavailable. Works only for agents reachable from Zabbix server/proxy (passive mode).
The critical threshold of the % Interrupt Time counter.
The threshold of the % Privileged Time counter.
The threshold of the Processor Queue Length counter.
The critical threshold of the CPU utilization expressed in %.
The warning threshold of the Memory Pages/sec counter.
The warning threshold of the Free System Page Table Entries counter.
The warning threshold of the Memory util item.
This macro is used in Network interface discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in Network interface discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in Network interface discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in Network interface discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in Network interface discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in Network interface discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in Service discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in Service discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in Service discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in Service discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
The warning threshold of the minimum free swap.
The threshold for difference of system time in seconds.
This macro is used in physical disks discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in physical disks discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
Disk read average response time (in s) before the trigger would fire.
The warning threshold of disk time utilization in percent.
Disk write average response time (in s) before the trigger would fire.
The critical threshold of the filesystem utilization.
The warning threshold of the filesystem utilization.
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
The critical threshold of the filesystem utilization in percent.
The warning threshold of the filesystem utilization in percent.

trigger.expression: min(/Windows by Zabbix agent/perf_counter_en["\System\Processor Queue Length"],5m) - last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/wmi.get[root/cimv2,"Select NumberOfLogicalProcessors from Win32_ComputerSystem"]) * 2 > {$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX}
trigger.name: Windows: CPU queue length is too high
trigger.event_name: Windows: CPU queue length is too high (over {$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX} for 5m)
trigger.description: The CPU Queue Length in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX}. According to actual observations, PQL should not exceed the number of cores * 2. To fine-tune the conditions, use the macro {$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX }.

trigger.expression: max(/Windows by Zabbix agent/system.swap.pfree,5m)<{$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN} and last(/Windows by Zabbix agent/system.swap.size[,total])>0
trigger.name: Windows: High swap space usage
trigger.event_name: Windows: High swap space usage (less than {$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN}% free)
trigger.description: This trigger is ignored, if there is no swap configured
